ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Complex analysis

Cauchy Riemann equations, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy Integral Formula, analytic iff holomorphic, power series, convergence, Laurent series, Liouville's Theorem, Cauchy differentiation formula, Cauchy estimates, maximum modulus principle, Jordan's lemma, residue theorem, Morera's theorem, argument principle, Rouche's theorem, mean value property of harmonic functions, analytic continuations

Basic complex analysis, with some applications mixed in. Cauchy-Riemann, Cauchy integral formula, power series, residue theorem, conformal maps, infinite products, harmonic analysis, and some analytic continuation

Fundamental ideas from Cauchy-Riemann
Analytic => real, imaginary are harmonic
Power series analytic in its disk of convergence
Cauchy's Theorem
Cauchy Integral Formal (+general w/ derivatives)
Analytic implies infinitely differentiable
Cauchy estimate
Liouville's theorem
Analytic implies exists expansion as power series
Uniqueness about analytic continuation
Morera's theorem
Uniform convergence on compact sets
MVT
Maximum Modulus Principle
Laurent's theorem (analytic  means you can expand as Laurent series)
Residue theorem
Argument principle
Rouche's theorem
Uniqueness of solutions to Dirichlet problem
Jordan's lemma
Poisson formula
Mean Value Property
Homotopy
I learned the fundamentals of complex analysis and how it can be applied to solve math problems from various fields.
Analytic functions, Cauchy's theorem (and the many results that follow from it), conformal maps, basics of harmonic functions/PDEs
Learned complex analysis and proof techniques related to the subject

This course gave me the foundations of complex analysis from a proof-based perspective and with some applications. Examples of the foundational results we covered include the Cauchy-Goursat theorem, the Cauchy Integral formula, Morera's theorem, the Laurent theorem, the residue formula, the argument principle, and Rouche's theorem. We also saw the applications of many of these principles to other situations, including the evaluation of real integrals using Jourdan's Lemma, a proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra using the Louisville theorem, and the Poisson kernel and mean value property of harmonic functions.
Complex analysis
Pretty much what was on the syllabus, plus some funny jokes.
I learned about complex analysis, and continued to work on formal proof writing.
Complex differentiation, integration, Cauchy's theorem/integral formulas, residue theorem, mean value theorem, argument principle
Complex analysis
Good survey of complex analysis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: you learn the big picture of complex analysis with Prof Schotland. Weaknesses: details get lost. Lots of errors in proofs and homeworks.

I thought the problem sets and exam did a great job reinforcing my grasp of the material and were also not too intense or time intensive. Highly recommend as a less intense math class that is still interesting. However, while I understand that the professor wants to cover more material by spending less time on details of proofs in class, I felt that proofs felt less rigorous than usual and often times important details would be omitted, leaving me confused in class since they're not explained properly.
Great class! We learned a ton and it was never really too stressful

Learned a lot of fundamental theorems for complex analysis and had challenging PSETs, but needed to learn some information on my own sometimes to complete PSET and watch videos to fully understand class material

Strengths: You learn the basics
Weaknesses: I was told complex analysis was the most beautiful math subject, but I wasn't really mind blown at any point in the class. Maybe if it were taught by another professor.

Strengths: content is organized very well, and it's all motivated and very clear

Weaknesses: some problem set questions were bad or boring. The graders were terrible and unfair

One obvious strength of this course was its clear structure. We saw that there are a few foundational results that both lay the groundwork for most of the results in complex analysis, and also establish intuition that makes the subject become more familiar as the course progressed. For the final exam, we had to learn the proofs of around 22 central results in the class  to reproduce on the exam. I felt this was a very valuable opportunity for me to go over details that I didn't understand upon seeing them fully the first time. I would like to note that I had several friends in the class who preferred to memorize the proofs by rote without trying to understand them. This course had a strong proof-based structure, but I also would have liked more examples of calculations that are possible with complex analysis, specifically when using branch cuts to evaluate integrals. This topic was present on one of the homework assignments but was only an aside in class. Lastly, this course did not closely follow the textbook. Although generally all of the results covered could be found in the textbook, sometimes the same name appeared as a slightly different theorem between class and the text. I believe that adhering more closely to the results in the textbook would have made this course easier to follow.

strength - really good TA
weakness - lectures were not exactly structured, many parts of the proof were left for us to figure out on our own
Its a good, coherent course. No complaints.

The strength of this course is that it is a very easy curriculum to follow topic by topic. The TA and teacher were great, and the other students were able to help each other. It was also nice to have topics that involved previous courses, making them easier to learn.

Strengths: textbook
Weaknesses: psets were inconsistently difficult
Need more involved problem sets.  Exam made me really learn the material though which is good
Lectures were a bit disorganized and there was no textbook really followed so it could be difficult to study.  Grading was harsh
Good lecturer, maybe more stuff about zeta function and analytic continuation would be nice

I thought the course was very interesting and mostly well-taught. However, a few of the concepts were not discussed in as much depth or rigor as I would like. The most notable case of this is that the course didn't at any point provide a rigorous foundation for multi-valued functions. in most cases it was not that difficult to work it out using intuition, but it left me feeling somewhat uncomfortable on problems involving path integrals across multiple branches, as well as later in the course when we discussed winding numbers. There were also a few homework problems with frustrating errors or somewhat unclear requirements.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The course is very interesting and provides a lot of useful tools for other areas of mathematics.
Yes. Just check who is teaching it. Prof Schotland is very big-picture-y, so you will have to sort out lots of details by yourself.
I would recommend since it's fundamental for the math major and it is a nice continuation of real analysis.
Do it! Complex analysis is beautiful. And JS is a great guy. As he says, he's not trying to hurt anybody. Easily one of the best times I've had in a class.
Indifferent, had its pros and cons
If you're majoring in math, complex analysis is a must.

Schotland is an OK lecturer, but not as rigorous as some other professors. He focuses on the main idea and asks you to fill in the details most of the time. This is sometimes frustrating because e.g., Cauchy's theorem has many versions and the one we proved is a very weak version. Also, we got a really harsh grader this semester, which is probably just bad luck, but something to keep in mind as a possibility.
Yes! The subject is beautiful and not a lot of work. Would 100% recommend to anyone with a basic understanding of analysis

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think that complex analysis is unique because of the breadth of its applications. Of all the pure math classes I have taken, this course was probably the most applicable to my area of physics. I think that physicists, mathematicians, and engineers could all benefit from this class.
I would recommend the course to the students who had prior exposure to the subject; those were the students who did really good in the class. The rest struggled a lot

Yes, 100%. Schotland is hilarious and is a great guy, his lectures were always entertaining though they drifted towards physics a few times (good for physics majors I guess). He wants everyone in the class to succeed, so the workload is not too insane but yet there are plenty of opportunities to get a solid background in complex analysis. The graders were atrocious this year but that's not Schotland's fault.
Its a good bread and butter math course. Yes.
I would recommend this course if needed for the student's major. That being said, I would recommend the teacher more so than the content itself.
Maybe, if they want to learn complex analysis.
Somewhat. Complex was complex
Yes, if you need it for the major

Yes. It's a good foundation for complex analysis and also includes a fair amount of practice with various methods for computing integrals (both complex ones and real ones not easily solvable through real methods).
